Yes, I can explain how panning affects the balance of instrumentals and vocals in the mix. Panning refers to the placement of audio signals within the stereo field, which is created by two speakers, one on the left and one on the right.

By panning different instruments to different positions within the stereo field, you can create a sense of spatial separation and depth in the mix. For example, if you pan a guitar to the left and a keyboard to the right, it will sound like the guitar is coming from the left side of the stage and the keyboard is coming from the right side.

This spatial separation can help create a clearer and more defined mix, allowing each instrument and vocal to occupy its own space in the mix. Without panning, all the sounds would be coming from the same location in the stereo field, leading to a less interesting and less dynamic mix.

When it comes to vocals, panning is generally used to create a sense of space, rather than to separate the vocals from other instruments. The lead vocal is typically panned to the center, while backing vocals or harmonies may be panned off to the sides to create a wider stereo image.

In summary, panning plays an important role in creating separation and depth in a mix, allowing each instrument and vocal to occupy its own space within the stereo field.
